Pregis is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. An appropriate response to releases of Isobutane is in the written Risk Management Program. Safety, environmental, and risk management programs are fully implemented and coordinated with community emergency responders for emergency planning and response. 

C. Hazard Assessment
The RMP requires the Pregis to evaluate the potential maximum potentially affected area for accidents involving the Isobutane for worst case release scenario and an alternative scenario.
The worst case release is highly improbable since it involves the combination of a certain set of conditions for a large release of the chemical without any employee intervention.  Because the assumptions required for the worst-case analysis are very conservative, the results likely will be very conservative. The endpoints specified for regulated flammable substances are intended to be protective of the general public. The distance to the endpoint estimated under worst-case conditions should not be considered an area in which the public would likely be in danger; instead, it is intended to provide an estimate of the maximum possible area that might be affected in the unlikely event of catastrophic accident. EPA intends the estimated distances to provide a basis for discussion among the regulated community, emergency responders, and the public, rather a basis for any specific actions.

A release from the 7,000-gallon Isobutane storage tank has been identified as the worst-case release and was considered in the hazard assessment. The maximum storage capacity of 7,000 gallons of Isobutane equates to approximately 32,833 lbs of Isobutane. Facility administrative controls allow the tank to be filled to 80% of capacity. The tank is located within a secondary containment area which would fully contain a spill from the tank. Thereby reducing the evaporation rate of the spill

These procedures assure that appropriate considerations are addressed prior to any change. Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are informed of, and trained in, the change prior to startup of the system. If a change results in the change in the process safety information, operation procedures, or practices, they will be updated accordingly.

Pre-Startup Safety Review: Pregis will perform a Pre-Startup Safety Review according to 40 CFR 68.67 when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information, equipment, operating procedures or practices.

Compliance Audits: Pregis will certify that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 every three (3) years. The compliance audit will be conducted by at least knowledgeable in the Isobutane system. A report of the findings of the audit will be developed. Pregis will promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports will be maintained. A compliance audit was conducted February 2016.

Incident Investigation: Pregis will investigate each incident, which results in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Isobutane. Incident investigations will be initiated as promptly as possible, as but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team will consist of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor. .The impact distance from the worst-case scenario has been estimated using EPA's RMPcomp Model. The impact distance from the RMPcomp Model results in an impact distance of 0.3 miles. The impact distance extends beyond the facility property.

The alternative scenario is an event more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario is more realistic accident scenario.  Pregis has determined that appropriate alternative scenario for the facility is process piping release from the process line carrying Isobutane from the tank to the pump room. The leak would release approximately 1066 lbs. of Isobutane. The RMPcomp Model estimates a distance to the endpoint of 0.05 mile the alternative release scenario.

D. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Process Safety Information: Pregis will complete a compilation of written safety information to be used in conducting the process hazard analysis (PHA). The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane System. The PHA will be conducted using the process safety information in order to identify and understand the hazards posed by the Isobutane system.

Process Hazard Analysis: Pregis will update and revalidate the PHA as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The PHA was conducted using  the What IF methodology, which is one of the methodologies specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including one member who has expertise in the Isobutane system and a member knowledgeable in the specified PHA methodology. A system was established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operation, maintenance

and other employees who may be affected by the recommendations or actions. The PHA was updated and revalidated in July 2016.

Operating Procedures: Pregis has developed written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where Isobutane is utilized. These written operating procedures will be consistent with the process safety information for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, safety systems and their functions. The operating procedures will be readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the Isobutane system. These operating procedures will be reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice. Pregis will certify annually that these operating procedures are current and accurate. Pregis will develop and implement safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the Pregis facility.

Training: Pregis will provide training for each employee associated with the Isobutane system. This training will include an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined in 40 CFR 68.67. Refresher training is provided every three (3) years or more often as necessary. Pregis documents and maintains records of employee training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity: Pregis will develop a written preventive maintenance program to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the Isobutane system (i.e., storage tanks, pumps, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed.
Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the Isobutane system components receives training at least every three (3) years or more often if necessary.

G. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
In an attempt to insure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training concerning this safety and environmental program and others will be conducted annually. This program requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the Isobutane system. Additionally, audits will be performed as specified in the RMP plan, which requires Pregis to assess areas of the RMP plan that may need to be changed or improved.

Executive Summary
A. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
Pregis, LLC (Pregis) is a specialty foam manufacturing facility which produces polyethylene (PE) foam, and structural polystyrene (SPS) Foam located in Tupelo, Mississippi. The PE foam manufacturing process also includes a laminated PE foam process. A Title V Permit Application renewal was submitted to Mississippi Department of Environmental Quality in July 2016.

The EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) is part of the Clean Air Act and applies to processes storing a specified chemical above a threshold quantity. The chemicals and threshold quantities are specified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Part 68. One such chemical is isobutane which is used as a blowing agent in the manufacturing process and is stored in excess of the threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

Polyethylene foam or PE foam is a plastic product made of polyethylene resin that is mixed with reclaimed product and additives, extrusion of the mixed resin through a highly specialized extruder; adding a liquid blowing agent (Isobutane), then cooling the material and forcing it through a die. The finished product is produced in variety of colors, thicknesses, and densities. The Isobutane is stored in three (3) storage tanks located in the tank farm.  The Isobutane Storage Tanks include one (1) 7,000) gallon and two (2) 6,000-gallon storage tanks with a combined maximum storage capacity of 19,000 gallons. The facility maintains administrative controls that allow the tanks to be filled to 80% of capacity which equates to 15,200 gallons or 71,280 pounds of Isobutane.

After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process. Based on the facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 3 of the RMP regulations.

Employee Participation: Pregis will develop a written plan of action regarding employee participation. The facility will consult with employees on the conduct and development of process hazard analysis and other elements of the system management. Pregis will provide employee access to hazard analysis and to all other information required to be developed under 40 CFR Part 68.

Hot Work Permit: Pregis will issue a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the Isobutane system.

Contractors: Pregis when selecting a contractor will obtain and evaluate information regarding the contract owner or operator's safety performance and programs. Pregis will inform the contract owner or operator of the known release hazards related to the contractor's work and the Isobutane system. Pregis will explain to the contract owner or operator of, the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan. Pregis will periodically evaluate the performance of the contract owner or operator in fulfilling their obligations as specified below. Contract owners or operators will assure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform their job. Contract owners or operators and Pregis will assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential release hazard related to their job and the Isobutane system and the applicable provisions of the Emergency Action Plan.

E. Five-year Accident History
Pregis has not had an accidental release of Isobutane that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite or any known off-site, death, injuries evacuations, sheltering in place, property, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five (5) years.
